title: One-minute questions
text:
After each class session, you are expected to give a brief summary of what happened in that session as well as pointing to things that either 1) were particularly meaningful to you or 2) that you found confusing.
These are called one-minute questions to indicate roughly how much time you should spend on your answer. Of course, you are welcome to spend more time. But even if you spend just one minute, your answer should be honest, articulate, and aimed at improving the class for yourself and your student colleagues.
Your answers will count toward class participation.
DO NOT write your answer while still in class.

title: About
text:
The University of Austin provides students with an extensive Intellectual Foundation curriculum. The IF courses are required of all students and taken in a student’s first or second year. Each course is taught synchronously to all students in each matriculation cohort; it is part of a shared experience.
There are two quantitative reasoning courses in the Intellectual Foundation curriculum. These are:

QR Analysis, which is about the concepts, techniques, and habits of mind that help people to make sense and use of quantitative information.
QR Data, which teaches modern data-science techniques to extract useful information from data.

Both QR Analysis and QR Data are unlike the introductory courses found at almost all other colleges and universities. We have selected topics based on their utility in modern professional work. In contrast, basic topics in the traditional curriculum reflect the historical development of mathematics rather than the needs of modern work. Modern topics widely used in the economy and scientific/technical worlds are relegated to so-called “advanced” courses far downstream where they are inaccessible to almost all students.
Our two QR courses dramatically streamline the pre-requisites for successful work with modern quantitative topics. Surprisingly often the “advanced” topics are readily accessible to students, so long as one is willing to move beyond traditional pedagogy and avoid unwarranted devotion to topics that were important historically but are no longer necessarily for understanding.

title: UATX Quantitative Reasoning - Analysis
text:
This page is oriented primarily to students registered in the course at the University of Austin, but visitors are welcome. General information for visitors is available via the About page.
A typical class week consists of one or two of the topics listed sequentially below and includes textbook readings, homework exercises, self-study drill questions, and a short weekly quiz.
Topics:

Modeling, the broad framework for quantitative reasoning
Quantities and dimensions
Rates and their uses
Magnitudes for handling the very big and the very small
Function building blocks. Functions are the links between quantities in our models.
Uncertain quantities. Functions also provide a way to represent uncertainty.
Custom design of functions, to power the models we build
Hypothesis and likelihood, to connect data to models and conclusion
Bayesian reasoning, updating our beliefs based on evidence
Dynamics, the study of systems that change in time
Rates of change, a revolution in quantitative thinking
Accumulation, the flip side of rates of change
